text.value: When Henry VIII of England met Francis I of France at the ‘Field of the Cloth of Gold’, the two men used the meeting to display their credentials as powerful leaders, even comparing the size of their thighs and lengths of their beards! Below are six points, only four of which are true. Identify the two points about Henry that are not made by Hans Holbein in the Whitehall Mural.

value.value: Though above his son, Henry VII is not in the foreground and is removed from the immediate scene by a step - he represents a previous era
She is probably there to underline his legitimacy. As a Yorkist (Henry VII was a Lancastrian), she also supports her son's claim to rule all England.
There are classical pilasters and a Latin inscription
Note the swagger and the codpiece
Lavish oriental carpets and gold filigree work.
again, the swagger and the dagger
Henry's father is greater than him in prestige and power
Henry clearly loves his mother, Elizabeth of York
Henry is a Renaissance man with an understanding of classical culture
Henry is fertile and sexually powerful
Henry is wealthy and his tastes are modern and fashionable
